title: 107_s2544
content: The "Great Lakes Legacy Act of 2002" is cited in this Act. Section 118(c)(3) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include a report on Remedial Action Plans. Grants are provided for the remediation of sediment contamination in areas of concern. Section 118(c) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include grants for remediation of sediment contamination in areas of concern, defining qualified projects as those monitoring, evaluating, remediating, or preventing further contamination of sediment in the United States. The Administrator may provide grants to States for qualified projects prioritizing remedial action for contaminated sediment, identified in a Remedial Action Plan and utilizing innovative remediation approaches. The Administrator may provide grants for qualified projects prioritizing remedial action for contaminated sediment, utilizing innovative approaches. Grants may not be given for projects in areas likely to suffer further contamination or without thorough site characterization. The Administrator coordinates with relevant parties to ensure efficient use of Federal and State assistance for remediation in areas of concern. Qualified projects subject to NEPA if they involve major activities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these projects. The Administrator conducts research on innovative approaches for sediment contamination remediation in the Great Lakes, with $50,000,000 authorized annually from 2004 to 2008. The funds remain available until expended. The Program Office may conduct a public information program by providing grants to various entities for public outreach in the Great Lakes region. $2,000,000 is authorized annually from 2004 to 2008, with funds remaining available until expended. The public information program provides grants for public outreach in the Great Lakes region, with $5,000,000 authorized annually from 2004 to 2008 for information sharing and coordination. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include cleanup and protection of the Great Lakes. SEC. 5 authorizes $40,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2008 for this purpose.
